answers.answer: It means you have nodules in the thyroid [focal lesions].The fluctuating TSH and non-uniform echotexture suggest some sort of thyroid inflammation.You may need to request blood test for TPO/TG and TSI antibodies to find if you have autoimmune thyroid disorder.
Correction did not notice report says without lessions, so its better news- no detectable nodules

question: I am a 37 year old woman recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.  I am 5'0 and 115lbs.  I have suffered from anxiety most of my adult life.  I have been living with chronic muscular pain, chronic fatigue, and migraines for years, however, over the past few months i have been so tired that it hurts.  I had blood work done on my thyroid and the first set demonstrated a low tsh, with normal t3 and t4.  We tested again and all were within normal range.  I insisted on checking again 6 months later and currently tsh was lower than the first time, t3 and t4 still normal.  Had an ultrasound with recent results "glad mildly heterogeneous in echotexture w/o sonographically detectable focus lesions..." gives measurements then states "the isthmus is normal in caliber measuring 3mm...there is no evidence of adenopathy, there are no extrathyroidal mass."   Can you give me a possible diagnosis?  Is ultrasound normal?  I was sent the results but have not been given a verbal explanation in lay terms.  Have been referred to endocronologists and instructed to complete further blood work.
title: abnormal tsh
